area_name: Forgotten Wall, Control Tower & Up The Creek Wall

content.description: Tricky sustained face climbing with a great finish.  Go left after the bulge.  If you go straight up you are on Losers Weepers which has the same start.
content.location: Starts under the oaks just right of a short right facing corner that is bolted.

content.description: A lot of cleaning was done to climb this route which is fun.  If the rock is bad you have not found the hold you want to use.  The crud can be avoided and most of the climbing is worth doing.  The bottom and the top both have some cool stuff.
content.protection: Bolts, Gear save a 4 camalot for the last move.  Some folks double up the Blue Camalots above the first bolt.
content.location: Left end of the Forgotten Wall.  Climb right angling crack to small corner with a bolt in it about 15 feet up.

content.description: Start up a moderate slab to a fun move onto a ledge.  Climb steep thin face then out right through the roof.  The climbing keeps getting harder with every bolt you clip, right to the final pull onto the ledge.
content.location:
Last route on the right side of Up the Creek Wall. 

  Starts 10 feet right of Blackwater.

content.description: 25 feet of easy 4th class climbing up to a ledge with a bolt that is right of a short, yellow, right-facing corner capped by a roof. The roof  extends right almost to the crack system that is Blackwater.  Turn roof and climb face to left facing corner.
content.location: This route is left of Blackwater which climbs a black stained crack system that leads to the left side of the big roof on the right side of the cliff

content.description: 115 foot pitch.     This route has sustained climbing with unusual face holds for Mt. Lemmon.
content.location: Starts a few feet right of the black streak roughly where the trail from the drainage meets the wall.  If you don't have a 70M rope there is a second set of anchors (you climb past them on the way up) to lower down to.  On the way down tie in straight, pull the rope, tie back into the rope and lower the rest of the way to the ground.

content.description: Thin interesting face climbing.
content.location: This is the left most route that starts under the oaks next to a right facing corner that forms a sharp arete.  Just left of Finders Keepers and Losers Weepers.

content.description:
Two crux bits will have to scratching you head.  The first has a stance allowing you to ponder at length. The roof, on the other hand, is go time.    The roof is not as hard as it looks once you know the beta.  

  Like all the climbs on the Forgotten Wall, the climbing stays interesting all the way to the chains.
content.location: 10 feet right of Cat on a Hot Thin Roof. Look for a bolt on the underside of the big roof.

content.description: This route climbs the very fun original start to Where's My Paddle but clips a bolt and heads left to the top of Blackwater.  Now the whole climb is closer to the grade rather than 5.9 crack to an 11+ finish.  The crux is after you join the top of Blackwater.
content.protection: Cams to Blue Camalot will do fine. 1 bolt
content.location: Starts up crack that eventually curves right as it toward the right side of the big roof.

content.description: This route has good trad pro when you need and a few bolts to supplement the gear.  Interesting crack climbing before the summit block will test you.
content.location: Left of the chimney on the west face.  Follow crack system up the back side.

climbs.name: Sweetie Don't Bite
climbs.fa: Creighton Chute, Jill Cooper, Erica Bigio, EFR,'07

content.description: This long route has some engaging sections.  A 70 meter rope will reach or lower to the anchors you pass as you lead the whole thing as one pitch.
content.location: Black streak right of the big dihedral.  Starts below a grassy ledge in the black streak.

content.description:
On the NE Face of the Control Tower, two routes require you to scramble up crap rock to a ledge.  Sundance is the LEFT route and climbs just right of the striking arete, using the big flake (with finger locks) for the first 20 feet.  Airworthy is the RIGHT-hand route on the NE Face.  Both routes have anchors, but for full value on Sundance, go to the (higher) Airworthy anchors, then use the Sundance anchor as a directional to clean the route. 

  Both of these routes go into the shade before 11 am.
content.location: NE Face of the Control Tower.  Scramble to ledge, follow left-hand bolt line to highest anchor.

content.description: This climb has the best seat in the house for threading the anchors.  Hard down low with a relatively easy finish out the left side of the big roof if you figure it out.  A slightly easier start known as the Cheap Seats Variation 5.10+ starts in the same spot but scrambles up the gully then steps from the flake to the wall.  Three bolts and you are on the upper part of Skybox.
content.location: Left side of the Forgotten Wall.  Starts just left of the chimney gully that leads to the top of a giant flake with a boulder on top.  It follows right angling holds and crack/seams up to the left side of 10ft. roof.

content.description: A little bit of funk on and around the ledge midway up the climb.  The climbing above and below that is good.  Climb bolted groove to ledge where chimney starts. Move left on to overhanging face.
content.location: Right of Blood Book which is the reddish orange crack/corner system on the right edge of the Forgotten Wall.

content.description: Fun stuff to the roof, hard pull over roof then a bit more business till it eases up and joins Candy Man.
content.location: Takes the obvious corner through the obvious roof just left of Cat On a Hot Thin Roof.   Joins Candy Man about half way up.

content.description: Pretty sustained until you move back to the left side of the arete.
content.location: About 60 feet right of Blood Book and slightly up the gully.

content.description: Short but fun face climbing with interesting features.  Good warmup.
content.location: Short face 15 feet right of Old and Creeky.GPS: 32.3561536, -110.7159834

content.description: Fun, easy move around the big roof, then a steep bit gets you to some slab and a final steep headwall.     Look for a thin flake that sticks out like a beak on the right side of the tower.
content.location: Climbs up to and out the left side of the big roof on the left side of Up the Creek Wall. From the ledge clip a bolt and head right via some steep slab then up the headwall.

content.description: Like the climbs to the left and the right this route is a puzzle and difficult to put together.  This will not get many onsights and those who do will claim the route is sandbagged.  Two distinct cruxes the first of which ends with hard to decipher move on to a ledge.  The second has a cool open hand sequence to hard moves over a roof.
content.location: Start just right of Collateral Damage which starts on a giant flake. climb easy gully chimney on left side of flake to get to ledge created by the top of the flake.  The route starts on top of two blocks that are leaning against the wall which allows one to get the high first bolt.

content.description: Stuff is a little crispy until you get up to the face that leads to the weakness in a small roof.  Above this is a neat corner system that is just left of an arete.  Originally called Tooth or Consequences Jimbo while redpointing this climb busted the tooth off.  He had been insisting it was going to break while I had been insiting otherwise.  He was right and we determined you can take a pretty good whipper and not hit the ledge.
content.location: Starts almost directly below the big Dihedral. Climb to a small ledge about six feet up clip a single bolt then pull on to a 4th class ramp that leads to a flake with two bolts.

content.description: Short silly looking climb that packs a lot of climbing into 30 feet.  Climb two cracks until you can pull over to the left one.
content.location: Right of Running with the Bulls

content.description: The crux is the first bulge but it doesn't let up a lot after that.
content.location: Starts the same as Finders Keepers under the oaks and just right of a short of a right facing corner with bolts on it.  After turning the bulge clip the reddish hanger and continue straight up the weakness.  If you work left you will be on Finders...

content.description: This climb has a few very thin moves and might be harder than 5.11.  We will see what the people think.  It is two pitches but shares the first pitch with Abandonment Issues.
content.location: Same start as Abandonment Issues.  At the first belay of Abandonment... head up and right.  You will share a few holds on Sweetie Don't Bite then work back left and up.

content.description: A good warmup for the other warm ups.  More interesting than it looks.
content.location: Starts 15 right of TBA also. Climbs face to arete just right of chimney flake.GPS: 32.3560557, -110.7157864

content.description: This is a short trad route that is in your face for two short cruxes.  Bomber gear in good crack make it safe or you can TR the thing from the anchors on Skybox.
content.protection: Gear to red camalot, You can look at it from the ground and pretty well figure out how much to take.
content.location: This short route starts to right of Skybox and climbs the crack system on the big flake.  Triangle roof to shallow dihedral lead to top of flake.  It ends roughly where Collateral Damage starts.

content.description: Getting to the stance to clip the bolt right of the roof is the trick to this climb.  Good pro and easier climbing above.
content.location: At the left edge of the south face of the Control Tower. Bolts lead to a roof that leads to a gear protected crack/corner above.GPS: 32.3553988, -110.717073

content.description: Start up 4th class ramp get some small gear in the corner then carefully work up to the only bolt on the climb.  Good gear will get you to the top.
content.protection: 1 bolt and lots of small cams and a singles to yellow camalot.
content.location: Right most of three routes starting on low angle ramp.

content.description: Start up 4th class ramp clip a bolt left of a small roof then head up face to a crack.  Some peopl use a 1 inch cam to protect moves to anchors.
content.protection: Bolts and maybe a 1 inch cam for move to anchors
content.location: Middle route of three on wall behind the Control Tower

content.description: Short route that starts by fourth classing up a ramp clipping a bolt then stepping left and climbing left of a small orange roof.  Half way up is a neat little layback crack.
content.protection: Light rack up to a red camalot and bolts
content.location: Left hand of three routes.

content.description: Climb the chimney.  A bit of funky rock.  Move left to get pro.
content.location: West face of Control Tower

content.description: Climb crack to low angle face. Wander up and around some unprotected roofs until you can get into a crack above them.
content.location: Ten feet left of Wreckless Abandon which has a bolt about 15 feet off the ground in a small corner.

content.description: Fun face climbing leads to a crazy traverse at the top.
content.location: 10 feet past A River Runs To It. Starts just left of a chimney flake.  Look for a small pine tree next to a bolt half way up climb.

climbs.name: Don't Grab Here
climbs.fa: Robert Fleugher, Adam Grad, Tom Weaver,Bill Clinch,'89

content.description: Crux is up high and bolt protected.  Getting there using bolts and good gear is fun.
content.protection: Bolts, light rack to yellow camalot.
content.location: To the right of the obvious roof on the Tower. Starts up steep broken juggy face then follows crack/seam to right side of roof.

content.description: Really tricky crux that is not intuitive.  The climb eventually works out the right side of the big roof.
content.location: Scramble up the gully on the left side of the giant flake and belay from on top.  When lowering off clip the perma draw to the end of the rope you are tied to so you don't end up 25 feet right.

climbs.name: Cat On A Hot Thin Roof

content.description: Good face and seam climbing to roof moves with thin face above.  Interesting ending too.
content.location: This climb starts about 30 feet right of Finders Keepers and 30 feet left of Blood Book.  Climb orange rick up seams to roof.  Undercling right then turn roofs.

content.description: The first thirty feet will get your attention and the last seventy will keep it.  Starts right of Finders Keepers turns a bulge with horizontal cracks in it.  Then follows weaknesses right until it heads straight up to the anchors.
content.location: Starts under the oaks in the middle of the wall just right of Finders Keepers

content.description: One of the best gear climbs in the grade.  Good pro all the way to the anchors.  Looks harder than it is.
content.protection: Standard rack with small cams up to 3 Camalot and two each of purple green and red.  Chains at the top for lowering when done.
content.location: Right side of the wall. It is an obvious right facing dihedral in an alcove that starts 20 feet above the trail at the base of the cliff.  It looks harder than it is.

content.description: A Mt. Lemmon trad climbing gem.     Bomber gear, and an awkward crux
content.protection: Rack of cams to 3 inches and some small tcu's, stoppers.   Chains
content.location: On Up the Creek Crag   A new formation 150 yards up stream from from the Control Tower.   Obvious line up a black streak through a small roof on the right side of the formation.

content.description: A tad forced as you must leave a crack and do some hard moves to reach the arete.  Once there it takes some hold on to get to the anchors
content.location: Starts below and left of Blood Book

content.description: Another chance to hand jam and crack climb on the Lemmon.    Climb crack for 10 feet to bolt, head to 2nd bolt above roof on left.    From ledge clip bolt then jam horizontally left to gain crack on headwall.
content.location: First route you come to on The Up the Creek Wall.GPS: 32.3559927, -110.7161308

content.description: Thin powerful crimping.  The last 20 feet make the middle 25 worth doing.
content.location: Right side of the Control Tower.  Start up crack that leads to a small ledge 25 feet up.

content.description: Low slightly awkward crux leads to fun face above.
content.location: Starts at the bottom of the chimney on the west face of the Control Tower but steps right from ledges.

content.description: The crack through the 5 foot roof is the crux.  It really helps to have a ton of tape or some crack gloves.  The jams are painful otherwise.  The left start is as tricky as the roof itself and makes the route a tad harder.
content.location: This route climbs the middle of the south face of the Control Tower.  It has two starts.  From the rocks to the left climb past a roof with a chain at the lip, or climb overhanging jugs up broken face directly below the roof.

content.description: A large right facing dihedral that is the most obvious feature on the wall.  It would get 3 stars if the rock at the bottom bolted part of the corner (2nd) pitch was a bit less grainy.  Pitch 1) 5.8 Climb face to nice belay ledge right of corner. 2) 5.11 Move left into corner then up dihedral past 4 or 5 bolts then start plugging gear.
content.protection: Bolts, standard rack to yellow camalots.  1/4 inch stopper is bombproof at the crux
content.location: Start 20 feet left of black streak where a block leans against the wall with a bolt.

content.description: Easy slab gains the arete.  Then steep face up and left around the corner.  Pumpy moves up the arete followed by a thin crux.
content.location: 10 feet right of Polar Bear Club

pathTokens: Forgotten Wall, Control Tower & Up The Creek Wall

content.description:
This wall faces south and can be climbed on the coldest of sunny days.  The face climbing is not as crimpy as Windy Point and there are a number of routes that climb through or around roofs.     The Control Tower is at the right end of the wall.  It has a 5ft. roof with a crack through it. At least three of the routes involve surmounting roofs.  The Up The Creek Wall is 100 yards past the Tower.  The areas rock is generally good but it has a bit of fuzz still coming off.  You do need to pay attention as there is some stuff around that you want to avoid.  If the rock seems bad there is a solid hold to be found somewhere. 40 plus routes from 5.9 to 12-   Many of the routes anchors have leaver biners so all you have to do is clip and lower off.  Two routes are 115 feet long and need a 70M rope.  Both these routes have an anchor part way up with leaver biners on them so if you have a 60M rope you can still get down. A lot of the routes have leaver biners so you just have to clip in and lower. 

  Overhead topo for locating routes: 

pikaconsulting.com/climbing…  (PDF File)
